questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He reports that he was wearing a helmet and that he did not lose consciousness. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97 per cent. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are a few bruises over his right chest, flank, and lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and non-tender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. The external genitalia appears normal. Complete blood count, prothrombin time, and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intra-abdominal fluid. An x-ray of the chest shows a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.correct_answer: B. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis A CT scan with a contrast of the abdomen and pelvis is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal injuries, including those of the genitourinary tract, in patients with blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) . BAT is a major cause of mortality among all age groups and should always be taken seriously, especially because a patient's initial presentation may be benign despite the significant intra-abdominal injury. Because this patient has a fracture of the 11th rib on the right side as well as microscopic haematuria on urinalysis following blunt abdominal trauma, a renal injury should be suspected. Therefore, a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

Highyeild:

Patients who have suffered abdominal trauma can generally be classified into the following categories based on their physiological condition after initial resuscitation: Physiologically ‘normal ’ – investigation can be completed before treatment is planned; Physiologically ‘non-compromised’ – investigation is more limited; it is aimed at establishing whether the patient can be managed nonoperatively, whether angioembolization can be used or whether surgery is required; Physiologically ‘compromised’ – investigations need to be suspended as immediate surgical correction of the bleeding is required. CT Scan CT has become the ‘gold standard’ for the intra-abdominal diagnosis of injury in the stable patient and can be performed using intravenous contrast. CT is sensitive to blood and individual organ injury as well as to retroperitoneal injury. An entirely normal abdominal CT is usually sufficient to exclude intraperitoneal injury The following points are important when performing CT: It remains an inappropriate investigation for physiologically compromised patients If the duodenal injury is suspected from the mechanism of injury, oral contrast may be helpful If the rectal and distal colonic injury is suspected in the absence of blood on rectal examination, the air around the colon may indicate injury ; in all cases, clinical suspicion supersedes investigation results

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Intravenous pyelography (IVP) is used for evaluation of possible renal disease, detection of renal stones, or to assess potential contrast extravasation if contrast enhanced CT images are not diagnostic. IVP was formerly a preferred imaging modality for renal trauma, but CT has supplanted IVP as the modality of choice. Option: C. Retrograde urethro-cystography is used to evaluate the lower genitourinary tract and urinary bladder. It is indicated in patients with gross haematuria or blood at the urethral meatus following a pelvic fracture. This patient, however, only has microscopic haematuria and no signs of a pelvic fracture. Therefore, retrograde urethro-cystography is not indicated at this time. Option: D. Observation and follow-up may be appropriate in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have no signs of traumatic injury. Although mild microscopic haematuria is common following blunt abdominal trauma and does not necessarily indicate genitourinary injury, this patient has evidence of a right rib fracture, which is concerning for a renal injury. Therefore, observation and follow-up would not be an appropriate next step.

Extraedge:

Effect of raised intra-abdominal pressure on individual organ function. System Effect Renal Increase in renal vascular resistance leading to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and impaired renal function Cardiovascular Decrease in venous return resulting in decreased cardiac output because of both a reduction in preload and an increase in afterload Respiratory Increased ventilation pressures because of splinting of the diaphragm, decreased lung compliance and increased airway pressures Visceral effects Reduction in visceral perfusion Intracranial effects Severe rises in intracranial pressures

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was on his way to work before he lost control of his car and crashed into a tree. On arrival, the patient appears weak and lethargic. He has pain in his abdomen. His temperature is 37 degrees C (98.6 degrees F), his pulse is 121/min, his respirations are 22/min, and his blood pressure is 85/60 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Abdominal examination shows several bruises above the umbilicus; there is diffuse abdominal tenderness. A focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is performed but the results are inconclusive. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage Although diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) has largely been replaced by FAST and CT scans, it is still indicated in trauma patients like this one who have an inconclusive FAST exam and are too hemodynamically unstable to be transported to a CT scan . A DPL is only performed for the purpose of ruling out the need for surgery. It is highly sensitive for detecting intraperitoneal blood and organ injury. A positive DPL is an indication of emergent laparotomy , whereas a negative DPL suggests an alternative cause for instability and is a contraindication for laparotomy .

Highyeild:

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage : Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is a test rarely used in modern-day practice but can be of value in resource-limited settings. It is a test used to assess the presence of blood or contaminants in the abdomen. Procedure : A nasogastric tube is placed to empty the stomach and a urinary catheter is inserted to drain the bladder. A cannula is inserted below the umbilicus, directed caudally and posteriorly. The cannula is aspirated for blood (>10 mL is deemed as positive) and, following this, 500 mL of warmed Ringer’s lactate solution is allowed to run into the abdomen from a 1-litre bag. The bag, with 500 mL remaining, is placed on the floor and the intra-abdominal fluid is allowed to flow under the influence of gravity – this aids drainage. Interpretations The presence of frank blood or similar contents to a nasogastric tube or urinary catheter denotes a positive DPL. If time allows and laboratory diagnosis is available, the presence of >100 000 red cells/µL or >500 white cells/µL is deemed positive (this is equivalent to 20 mL of free blood in the abdominal cavity), as is a raised amylase level. In the absence of laboratory facilities, a urine dipstick may be useful. Drainage of lavage fluid via a chest drain indicates penetration of the diaphragm .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. In torso trauma, the best and most sensitive modality is a CT scan with intravenous contrast; however, in an unstable patient, this is generally not possible. Option: B. Exploratory laparotomy is indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with evidence of perforated viscus, as well as patients with clear and persistent peritonitis, radiologic evidence of pneumoperitoneum, evidence of diaphragmatic rupture, or persistent and significant GI bleeding seen on nasogastric suction/vomitus. Because this patient's FAST exam was inconclusive, confirmation of an intraabdominal cause is required before exploratory laparotomy would be indicated. If a hemodynamically unstable patient has an extra-abdominal cause of instability (e.g., thoracic injury, long bone fracture) and undergoes unnecessary laparotomy, the true underlying cause may be missed, leading to continued deterioration and likely death. Option: C. Abdominal radiography may detect intra-abdominal free air or large amounts of free fluid, both of which could be caused by blunt abdominal trauma. However, an abdominal X-ray is not used in the initial workup of abdominal trauma because it is insensitive and requires confirmatory testing (e.g., a CT scan).

Extraedge:

Although DPL has largely been replaced by eFAST, it remains the standard in many institutions where eFAST is not available or is unreliable.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 40 minutes after being involved in a shooting. He sustained a gunshot wound in an altercation outside of a bar. On arrival, he is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 37.3 degrees C (99.1 degrees F), his pulse is 116/min, his respirations are 18/min, and his blood pressure is 79/42 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97 per cent. Examination shows multiple abrasions over the arms and thorax. There is a 1-cm (0.4-in) entry wound with minimal bleeding on the right side of the chest in the 6th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. A focused assessment with sonography shows no obvious free fluid in the pericardium; the assessment of the abdomen is equivocal. An x-ray of the chest shows mild opacification of the right lower lobe. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. The patient is intubated and mechanical ventilation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Chest tube insertion in the 5th intercostal space at the midaxillary line

options.label: B
options.text: CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exploratory Laparotomy An exploratory laparotomy is indicated in patients with a penetrating abdominal wound who are hemodynamically unstable. Gunshot wounds commonly injure the small bowel, colon, and liver, and a FAST exam cannot rule out all sources of abdominal bleeding. During expiration, the dome of the diaphragm may reach as high as the fourth intercostal space on the right and the fifth intercostal space on the left. For this reason, any penetrating injury below this level is treated as if it involves both the thoracic and abdominal cavities. Although this patient may also have a diaphragmatic and/or pulmonary injury, as indicated by the right lower lobe opacities seen on the chest X-ray, this is unlikely to be responsible for his hypotension and tachycardia. Given the site of injury and equivocal FAST exam , an exploratory laparotomy is indicated to assess for potential intra-abdominal injuries that may be the cause of his hemodynamic instability.

Highyeild:

Patients who have suffered abdominal trauma can generally be classified into the following categories based on their physiological condition after initial resuscitation: Physiologically ‘normal ’ – investigation can be completed before treatment is planned; Physiologically ‘non-compromised’ – investigation is more limited; it is aimed at establishing whether the patient can be managed nonoperatively, whether angioembolization can be used or whether surgery is required; Physiologically ‘compromised’ – investigations need to be suspended as immediate surgical correction of the bleeding is required. Laparotomy : Laparotomy is the final step in the pathway to delineate intra-abdominal injury. Occasionally it is difficult to determine the source of bleeding in shocked, multiple-injured patients. If doubt still exists, especially in the presence of other injuries, a laparotomy may still be the safest option. The key is to make a decision, as indecision leads to a delay in definitive control.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Insertion of a chest tube into the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line is indicated for haemothorax. Haemothorax may develop as a result of a gunshot wound and manifests with chest pain, dyspnoea, decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and, in some cases, haemorrhagic shock. However, this patient has a normal pulmonary examination and absence of any signs of haemothorax on chest x-ray, making this diagnosis unlikely. Option: B. CT scan is used to assess patients with penetrating abdominal wounds if they are stable on examination. It helps detect intra-abdominal bleeding and assess the extent of the injury. A CT scan is not indicated in this hemodynamically unstable patient because there is a risk that his state may worsen in the time it takes to obtain the scan. Patients without signs of peritonitis, evisceration, or hemodynamic instability may undergo CT prior to surgical intervention. Option: C . Local wound exploration can be used to evaluate the depth and tract of stab wounds and to determine if the peritoneal violation has occurred. However, it would not be appropriate in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after colliding with a motor vehicle during a professional cycling competition. He has urinated once since the accident, and the urine had a reddish hue. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.2 degrees C (98.6 degrees F), his pulse is 100/min, his respirations are 25/min, and his blood pressure is 105/68 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows abrasions and a purple-red discolouration over his right flank. There is costovertebral tenderness on the right. His haemoglobin concentration is 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6,000/mm3, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3. Electrolytes are within normal limits and creatine kinase concentration is 89 U/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: CT- Scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.correct_answer: B. CT- Scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT- Scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast CT imaging with contrast is the next best step in a hemodynamically stable patient with suspected renal trauma. A contrast CT is used to determine the severity of renal trauma, as this will dictate further management (surgical exploration vs. observation)

Highyeild:

Renal Trauma: Kidneys are retroperitoneal structures; they are relatively fixed by their vascular pedicles and are well protected by perinephric fat, strong posterior abdominal wall muscles and the lower rib cage. Renal trauma is usually a part of polytrauma and is present in only 5% of all trauma cases. Mechanism Of Injury : Trauma may be penetrating or blunt, the latter being far more common Common Modes : Head-on collisions in road traffic accidents Falls from height Contact sports Sudden rapid deceleration (Avulsion Injury to ureter at PUJ) Penetrating injuries cause direct tissue disruption and are usually associated with adjacent organ injuries Presentation : Loss of Consciousness Haemodynamic Shock Haematuria (Pathognomic) Abdominal Pain with flank contusions Diagnosis : CECT of the abdomen is necessary to delineate the type and extent of renal injury. It provides information about the presence of parenchymal laceration, its depth, extension into the pelvicalyceal system and the extent of urinary extravasation It also provides valuable information about other abdominal injuries and the status of the contralateral kidney. Common indications for CECT in abdominal trauma include: Abdominal trauma with gross haematuria Microscopic haematuria with hypotension (systolic <90 mmHg) Rapid deceleration injury Children with microscopic haematuria (>5 red blood cells [RBCs]) All penetrating injuries. Indications for emergency surgical exploration are: expanding or pulsatile retroperitoneal haematoma PUJ avulsion renal pedicle injury haemodynamic instability Treatment : Conservative management with close surveillance is sufficient in the majority of cases of isolated renal trauma. Lower-grade injuries, sometimes including grade IV, can be managed conservatively with bed rest, antibiotics in case of penetrating injuries and serial haemoglobin estimation. Reimaging is usually done after 2–4 days in cases of falling haemoglobin levels, fever or expanding fank mass. A persistent urinary leak can be managed with an internal DJ stent or PCN.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. In the trauma setting, urinalysis is occasionally performed on patients with suspected renal injury in the absence of gross haematuria as a rapid, inexpensive test to detect microscopic haematuria (which may be indicative of renal laceration). However, this patient has macroscopic haematuria. Regardless, severe renal trauma may present without gross or microscopic haematuria, rendering urinalysis a poor test for diagnosing the renal injury and evaluating its severity. Option: C. Retrograde pyelography cannot visualize the renal parenchyma and is therefore not useful in assessing the severity of the renal injury. It is, however, highly sensitive in diagnosing the ureteral injury, which may also present with haematuria, as seen here. But ureteral injury following external trauma is rare ( less than 3 per cent of cases of genitourinary trauma). Moreover, retrograde pyelography is an invasive procedure, meaning it should only be performed if the first-line diagnostic test is inconclusive. Option: D. Although ultrasonography can diagnose some renal lacerations, it cannot reliably identify injuries to the vascular pedicle, and cannot differentiate between retroperitoneal haemorrhage and extravasation of urine.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision where she was the unrestrained driver. She was found thrown across the dashboard of the car. On arrival, she appears lethargic. She is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 133/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm laceration over the right upper extremity. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are multiple bruises over the chest and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and not distended. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. 0.9 per cent saline infusion is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ultrasonography Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is an essential component of management for blunt abdominal trauma. This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision and is hemodynamically unstable, which is concerning for intraperitoneal bleeding . The FAST exam screens for free fluid, especially blood.

Highyeild:

Focused abdominal sonography for trauma and extended FAST (FAST and eFAST) Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) is a technique whereby ultrasound (sonography) imaging is used to assess the torso for the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity and is extended into the thoracic cavities and pericardium (eFAST). There should be no attempt to determine the nature or extent of the specific injury. eFAST is usually a rapid, reproducible, portable and non-invasive bedside test and can be performed at the same time as resuscitation. eFAST is accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood ; however, it is very operator dependent and, especially if the patient is very obese or the bowel is full of gas, it may be unreliable. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose , even in experienced hands, as small amounts of gas or fluid are difficult to assess and eFAST has a low sensitivity (29–35%) for organ injury without hemoperitoneum . eFAST is also unreliable for excluding injury in penetrating trauma . If there is doubt, the eFAST examination can be repeated.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Exploratory laparotomy would not be the first step in managing blunt abdominal trauma. Other diagnostic approaches must be considered to investigate why this patient is hemodynamically unstable. However, in the case that no other resources are readily available, exploratory laparotomy should be pursued if there is high clinical suspicion of intraperitoneal haemorrhage. Option: B. A CT scan of the abdomen would not be the next best step for managing this unstable patient. Although a CT scan can also show the presence of a hemoperitoneum, it takes time and unnecessarily exposes the patient to radiation when other more rapid diagnostic studies are available. Option: D. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) would not be the most appropriate next step because other less invasive and more readily available diagnostic studies should be available to assess for intra-abdominal bleeding. A DPL can be considered when other diagnostic studies are unavailable or equivocal.

Extraedge:

Effect of raised intra-abdominal pressure on individual organ function. System Effect Renal Increase in renal vascular resistance leading to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and impaired renal function Cardiovascular Decrease in venous return resulting in decreased cardiac output because of both a reduction in preload and an increase in afterload Respiratory Increased ventilation pressures because of splinting of the diaphragm, decreased lung compliance and increased airway pressures Visceral effects Reduction in visceral perfusion Intracranial effects Severe rises in intracranial pressures

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 x 3 cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and an infusion of 0.9 per cent saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid haemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings? Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B In case of acute trauma, a Glasgow coma Scale score of less than or equal to 8 is an indication for urgent endotracheal intubation . A patient who opens their eyes to pain makes incomprehensible sounds, and has to decorticate posture (or abnormal flexion) would receive a total GCS score of 7 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for a verbal response, and 3 for motor response). GCS assessment is part of the primary trauma survey in any trauma patient to evaluate neurological status, consciousness, and degree of brain injury. A GCS score of ≤ 8 indicates severe brain injury with a decreasing level of consciousness, which requires emergency endotracheal intubation to protect the patient's airway and reduce the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

Highyeild:

Glasgow Coma Scale Score: The initial assessment of the trauma patient includes the primary survey, resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care. Neurosurgical evaluation begins during the primary survey with the determination of the GCS score (usually referred to simply as the GCS) for the patient. The GCS is determined by adding the scores of the best responses of the patient in each of the three categories. The motor score ranges from 1 to 6, verbal from 1 to 5, and eyes from 1 to 4. The GCS, therefore, ranges from 3 to 15 Tracheal intubation or severe facial or eye swelling can impede verbal and eye responses. In these circumstances, the patient is given a score of 1 with a modifier, such as verbal “1T” where T = tube

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal commands is oriented and obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 14 (3 for eye-opening, 5 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 14 indicates only mild head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation Option: C. A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal commands, speaks confused or disoriented words, and localizes pain would receive a GCS score of 12 (3 for eye-opening, 4 for verbal response, and 5 for motor response). A GCS score of 12 indicates only mild head injury and would not be an indication of endotracheal intubation. Option: D. A trauma patient who opens their eyes to the pain and makes incomprehensible sounds but obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 10 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 10 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication of endotracheal intubation. To pain Incomprehensible sounds Abnormal flexion

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after sustaining a gunshot wound to the neck. She did not lose consciousness. On arrival, she has severe neck pain. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37 degrees C (98.6 degrees F), her pulse is 105/min, her respirations are 25/min, and her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96 per cent. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows a bullet entrance wound in the right posterior cervical region of the neck. There is no exit wound. Carotid pulses are palpable bilaterally. There are no carotid bruits. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT Angiography The patient has suffered a gunshot wound to the neck but presents with stable vital signs and a normal physical examination. Stable patients with penetrating neck injuries should be evaluated for possible injuries to the trachea, larynx, and neck vessels. Multidetector CT angiography is the recommended imaging modality for the evaluation of these injuries.

Highyeild:

Zone I extends from the thoracic inlet to the cricoid cartilage and contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and esophagus. Stretching from the cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible, Zone II is the most accessible surgically and contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract . Zone III includes the neck between the angle of the mandible and the base of the skull . Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically . Although zone II injuries with the physical exam are indicators for the depth of injury (i.e., violation of platysma) traditionally mandated operative exploration, it has since been recognized that only those patients with hard signs of vascular or aerodigestive injury require immediate operation while the remainder may undergo radiographic assessment (so-called “no-zone” approach) (MDCTA) MultiDetector Computed Tomography Angiography : CT angiographic evaluation of the neck, performed in the emergency department, has become readily available and decreased the rate of negative neck explorations for penetrating injury Stable patients may undergo further evaluation for neck injury with thin-slice multidetector CT angiography (MDCTA) imaging.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Surgical exploration is indicated in patients with a penetrating neck injury who show signs of decompensation, an expanding hematoma, or a tracheal/oesophageal injury. Although this patient is tachycardia and tachypnoeic (most likely due to a sympathetic response to pain), she is normotensive and has normal oxygen saturation. She also has no signs of expanding hematoma, subcutaneous emphysema, or ongoing bleeding. Consequently, surgical exploration is not indicated at this time. Option: C. A gunshot wound to the neck may require intubation, most commonly because of a tracheal injury or an expanding neck hematoma that compromises the airway. The patient in this vignette does not have an expanding hematoma and has no signs of tracheal injury (e.g., stridor, subcutaneous emphysema, haemoptysis) or respiratory distress. Her vital signs are stable, she is neurologically intact, and she has normal oxygen saturation, so there is no indication of endotracheal intubation. Option: D. Laryngoscopy may be indicated for the diagnosis of occult injury to the larynx, but it is not the preferred initial diagnostic modality in a patient with a penetrating neck injury. Moreover, this patient does not have any signs of laryngeal injury (e.g., stridor, dysphonia, haemoptysis).

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. On arrival, she has shortness of breath, right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and right shoulder pain. She is otherwise healthy. She takes no medications. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 115/min, her respirations are 20/min, and her blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Examination shows several ecchymoses over the right chest. There is tenderness to palpation over the right chest wall and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liver Hematoma A liver hematoma commonly results from blunt abdominal trauma such as falls. This patient has the typical features of liver injury, including ecchymoses over the right chest, pain in the right upper quadrant and the right chest, referred pain to the right shoulder (due to diaphragmatic irritation), and hemodynamic instability.

Highyeild:

Liver Trauma: Liver injury due to blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma is second in frequency only to that of the spleen. Blunt injury produces contusion, laceration and avulsion, often associated with splenic, mesenteric or renal injuries. (Common & has high Mortality) Penetrating injuries , including stab and gunshot wounds , are often associated with chest or pericardial involvement. Complications: Intrahepatic haematoma Liver abscess Bile collection Biliary fistula Haemobilia Ascites Biliary strictures Intra-abdominal collections Hepatic artery aneurysm Arteriovenous fistula Arterio Biliary fistula Liver failure Diagnosis: The liver is an extremely well-vascularised organ and blood loss is the major early complication following injury A high index of suspicion is essential with any chest or upper abdominal stab wound, especially where significant blood loss is obvious . Severe crushing injuries to the lower chest or upper abdomen frequently result in rib fractures, haemothorax and splenic and/or liver injury. Penetrating injuries are frequently associated with massive, continued blood loss and coagulopathies ; transfer to the operating theatre should occur while blood products are obtained and resuscitation continues. Focused assessment sonography in trauma (FAST) performed by an experienced operator will identify free intraperitoneal fluid. In haemodynamically unstable patients with penetrating wounds, a laparotomy and/or thoracotomy is indicated once active resuscitation has commenced In haemodynamically stable patients , an urgent contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest and abdomen is performed to look for parenchymal injury and concomitant damage to other thoracic or abdominal organs

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The spleen is one of the most commonly injured organs during blunt abdominal trauma. Severe haemorrhage associated with splenic laceration often results in tachycardia and hypotension, which is seen in this patient. However, rather than right-sided pain, patients with splenic injury usually experience left-sided abdominal pain and left shoulder pain (“Kehr sign”). Option: B. Pneumothorax may occur secondary to blunt chest trauma such as a fall. It presents with dyspnoea and ipsilateral chest pain, as well as hemodynamic instability in the case of tension pneumothorax (due to mediastinal compression and decreased venous return). However, the physical examination in patients with pneumothorax typically shows reduced or absent breath sounds over the affected lung. Tension pneumothorax would also manifest with jugular venous distention rather than the flat neck veins seen in this patient. Option: D. Duodenal hematoma is a common injury in children who suffer blunt abdominal trauma. In children, the abdominal wall is thinner and less developed, and inner organs, especially the duodenum, take up a larger portion of the body relative to height, making them more prone to injury. Typical symptoms, such as epigastric pain, bilious emesis, and an upper abdominal mass, resulting from the associated small bowel obstruction. The absence of these symptoms in combination with the patient's age makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for possible injury during football practice. While running for a touchdown, the patient was tackled from the front and fell to the ground with another player landing on top of him. Immediately after he started to experience abdominal discomfort, nausea, and left-sided chest and shoulder pain. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. His blood pressure is 106/67 mm Hg, his pulse is 107/min, and his respiration is 24/min. The patient is diaphoretic and appears anxious. Heart sounds are normal without murmur. Bilateral breath sounds are clear and equal. He has left chest wall tenderness. The abdomen is mildly distended and tender with decreased bowel sounds. The range of movement of the left shoulder is full and not painful. Further evaluation of this patient is likely to reveal which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenic laceration This patient's presentation is concerning possible blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) (abdominal tenderness) and blunt thoracic trauma (BTT) (chest wall tenderness) following a football injury. Tachycardia (or hypotension) is concerning for haemorrhage due to a solid organ or vascular injury. The most common intra-abdominal organ injuries due to BAT are splenic and hepatic lacerations. Splenic injury is most likely in the setting of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and left chest wall and shoulder pain without evidence of abnormalities of the shoulder (likely referred pain due to phrenic nerve irritation from splenic haemorrhage). The next step in the evaluation should include a focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) to identify signs of haemorrhage.

Highyeild:

The spleen is the most commonly injured intra-abdominal organ followed by the liver . Splenic rupture should be considered in any case of blunt abdominal trauma , particularly when the injury occurs to the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Iatrogenic injury to the spleen remains a frequent complication of any surgical procedure, particularly those in the left upper quadrant when adhesions are present . I ndications for splenectomy Trauma • Accidental • latrogenic Haematological • Spherocytosis • Purpura (ITP) • Hypersplenism Oncological • Part of en bloc resection • Diagnostic • Therapeutic Portal hypertension • Variceal surgery

BAT infrequently leads to vascular injury of the mesenteric or pelvic vessels (more likely with pelvic fractures) whereas BTT is more commonly associated with aortic injury. However, the most common mechanisms resulting in significant aortic injury are rapid deceleration injuries such as motor vehicle collisions at high speeds, falls from more than 3 m (10 ft), or severe crush injuries. Moreover, patients with aortic trauma frequently have significant comorbid injuries such as fractures, neurological deficits, cardiac murmurs, and upper extremity hypotension. Option: B. Pneumothorax is a frequent complication from BTT, however Patients usually present work unequal breath sounds on the affected side in addition to other signs, such as tachypnoea and chest pain. Option: C. Small bowel perforation can occur due to mesenteric vascular injury with subsequent ischemia and necrosis. However, perforation due to blunt trauma more commonly presents several days after the initial events with fever haemodynamic instability and diminished bowel sounds. Acute presentations are more common in penetrating trauma

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after the motor vehicle collision. He was the restrained driver when a truck hits his car on the driver-side at an intersection. He was dazed for several minutes after the collision and subsequently began to experience left chest and leg pain. His blood pressure is 94/61 mm of Hg and his pulse is 117 per minute. Pulse oximetry shows 96 per cent on room air. The patient is conscious and answers question appropriately. He is wearing a cervical collar. Physical examination shows multiple facial lacerations and bruises on the left chest wall. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Heart sounds are normal. The trachea is midline. Bilateral breath sounds are present. The abdomen is diffusely tender. There is obvious deformity and tenderness in his left thigh. Which of the following is the best immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Focused bedside ultrasound This patient presents after the motor vehicle collision with diffuse abdominal tenderness concerning blunt abdominal trauma which places him at significant risk of intra-abdominal injury. A number of signs are suggestive of serious intra-abdominal injury, including seatbelt sign (ecchymosis over the abdomen in the pattern of a seatbelt), hypotension, rebound tenderness, abdominal guarding/distension and coexisting femur fracture. The first step after fluid resuscitation is to determine if a patient needs surgical management. Patience with blunt abdominal trauma should be assessed for intraperitoneal free fluid or haemorrhage. The most commonly used approach is the focus assessment which is sonography for trauma (FAST) , which evaluates both the abdomen and pericardium for evidence of organ injury or haemorrhage.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Chest CT scan is Indicated in hemodynamically stable patients with multisystem injury and suspected injury to the aorta and those with an abnormal chest x-ray showing mediastinal abnormalities Option: C. This patient with blunt abdominal drama should be evaluated for an intra-abdominal injury and has no high-risk criteria for a head injury requiring emergent head CT (eg- low GCS, Signs of basilar fracture, repeated vomiting) Option: D. Evaluation of the femur fracture is a lower priority in a patient with blunt abdominal drama and haemodynamic instability than a focused evaluation for evidence of haemorrhage.

questions.text: Morbidly obese 40- year- old male suffered a right flank gunshot wound. He’s haemodynamically normal and has a benign abdominal examination. On physical examination, you find a bullet hole on his mid-right flank and another hole more posteriorly on his right MID mid back. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT Abdomen/Pelvis This patient suffered a flank gunshot wound and is haemodynamically normal without peritonitis . Given that the majority of flank gunshot wounds do not penetrate the peritoneal cavity, the next best step is to obtain a CT scan to delineate the trajectory of the bullet . If the bullet clearly did not violate the peritoneum he can safely be discharged .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A & D. Thus, neither immediate laparotomy nor serial abdominal examination is indicated. Option: B. Since the patient is hemodynamically normal and has a benign abdominal examination FAST is not required.

questions.text: A 25- year- old male presents with a stab wound to the neck at the level of the cricoid cartilage. The primary survey reveals a patent airway, equal breath sounds, and palpable femoral pulses. He is haemodynamically stable. A secondary survey reveals no additional injury. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CTA of the neck Haemodynamically stable patients with penetrating trauma should undergo CT Angiography to determine the trajectory prior to possible operative management.

Highyeild:

Zone I extends from the thoracic inlet to the cricoid cartilage and contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and esophagus. Stretching from the cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible, Zone II is the most accessible surgically and contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract . Zone III includes the neck between the angle of the mandible and the base of the skull . Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically . Although zone II injuries with the physical exam are indicators for the depth of injury (i.e., violation of platysma) traditionally mandated operative exploration, it has since been recognized that only those patients with hard signs of vascular or aerodigestive injury require immediate operation while the remainder may undergo radiographic assessment (so-called “no-zone” approach) Computed Tomography Angiography : CT angiographic evaluation of the neck, performed in the emergency department, has become readily available and decreased the rate of negative neck explorations for penetrating injury. Stable patients may undergo further evaluation for neck injury with thin-slice multidetector CT angiography (MDCTA) imaging.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Emergent neck exploration is indicated in haemodynamically unstable patients. Option: C & D. Bronchoscopy and Esophagoscopy are indicated when there is suspected tracheal and esophageal injury respectively and CTA is equivocal.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man, a passenger in the right front seat of the vehicle, was wearing a 3-point seatbelt at the same time as a head collision traffic accident. On admission, he was conscious, vitals normal, and had no external demonstrable injury. Abdominal tenderness was present in the initial physical examination without any other obvious findings. The most common organ injured can be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mesentery

Highyeild:

Seat belt injury: The use of seat belts is associated with an injury profile known as seat belt syndrome The most common structure injured is mesentery Classical seat belt sign: Skin abrasion over the neck Skin abrasion on chest Skin abrasion on the abdomen. Caused by sudden deceleration – mesentery tear May compress pancreas over vertebral column --- pancreaticoduodenal injury.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient was admitted to the emergency dept after a road traffic accident. He was unconscious during the admission, h/o vomiting present. there were no associated h/o co-morbidities, seizures or any bleeding from the nose. there were some restrictions on movements in his lower limbs. On examination, PR – 100/min, BP- 100/80 mm Hg, RR- 36 / min, GCS – 3/15. On the chest, examination diminished breath sounds. Chest X-ray was done and showed LT pneumothorax and 1- 6 ribs fracture on the right side. What is the method of back examination you will use in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Log roll The logroll manoeuvrer is performed to evaluate the patient’s spine and remove the long spine board while limiting spinal movement. One person stands at the patient’s head to control the head and c-spine, and two are along the patient’s sides to control the body and extremities. As the patient is rolled, three people maintain alignment of the spine while the fourth person removes the board and examines the back. Once the board is removed, three people return the patient to the supine position while maintaining the alignment of the spine. Per rectum, the examination is also performed during this time only In case 5 people are not available then, a total of 4 persons are mandatory .

questions.text: A 30- year- old man came to a casualty with RTA, where his car met with an accident with a heavy vehicle. On admission, he was hemodynamically stable. On examination, his GCS was quite normal and had no evidence of head injury. On per abdominal examination, no distension was present, guarding was absent and mild tenderness was seen below the right hypochondrium. FAST was done which suggests:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Positive FAST Positive FAST: The appearance of a dark ("anechoic") strip in the dependent areas of the peritoneum. In the right upper quadrant, this typically appears in Morison's Pouch (between the liver and kidney). In the left upper quadrant, blood may collect anywhere around the spleen (peri-splenic space). Branney and colleagues determined that the mean minimum detectable free-fluid volume during FAST examination was 619 mL in the Morison pouch Trendelenburg positioning may improve visualization of free fluid in the splenorenal and hepatorenal interface.

Highyeild:

Focused abdominal sonography for trauma and extended FAST (FAST and eFAST) Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) is a technique whereby ultrasound (sonography) imaging is used to assess the torso for the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity and is extended into the thoracic cavities and pericardium (eFAST). There should be no attempt to determine the nature or extent of the specific injury. eFAST is usually a rapid, reproducible, portable and non-invasive bedside test and can be performed at the same time as resuscitation. eFAST is accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood ; however, it is very operator dependent and, especially if the patient is very obese or the bowel is full of gas, it may be unreliable. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose , even in experienced hands, as small amounts of gas or fluid are difficult to assess and eFAST has a low sensitivity (29–35%) for organ injury without hemoperitoneum . eFAST is also unreliable for excluding injury in penetrating trauma . If there is doubt, the eFAST examination can be repeated.

questions.text: A 30- year- old patient met with RTA after colliding with a heavy vehicle. On admission, he was hemodynamically stable. On examination, n evidence of severe head injury was seen but on abdominal examination, some lacerations were seen. After all the blood and biochemical tests they were found to be within the normal limits. On further examination that is on CT, the left renal parenchyma was found to have lacerations with mild urinoma. As the patient was stable so conservative management was decided. Even after 14 days the urinoma persists, but he was stable with no h/o fever. The next step in management would be-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Shaped urinary stent Minor renal injuries from blunt trauma account for 85 % of cases and do not usually require an operation. The bleeding stops spontaneously with bed rest and hydration, that is with conservative management Cases in which operation is indicated include those associated with persistent retroperitoneal bleeding, urinary extravasation and renal pelvis injuries Even after 14 days, if urinoma persists then there is a need for stenting so that it can be drained out in time and broad-spectrum antibiotics are given to such patients to avoid the risk of infection. Also, for the same reason proper aseptic measures should be taken for the patient.

questions.text: A 20- year- old male was admitted to ER with RTA and some penetrating wounds in his abdomen. On admission, he was managed according to the ATLS protocol. On presentation, he was conscious, and oriented, with no cyanosis with hypotension and hemodynamically unstable. on examination, the abdomen was distended not moving with respiration, there was tenderness all over with guarding present. tympanic on percussion and sluggish bowel sounds. The X-rays done were inconclusive, the next step in management would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Local wound exploration and wound suturing

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exploratory laparotomy If the source of the bleeding is in doubt or FAST/CT results are positive, showing a significant amount of blood in the peritoneal cavity, concurrent intra-abdominal injury cannot be excluded and it is wise to perform an exploratory laparotomy to treat or rule out intra-abdominal bleeding.

Highyeild:

Patients who have suffered abdominal trauma can generally be classified into the following categories based on their physiological condition after initial resuscitation: Physiologically ‘normal ’ – investigation can be completed before treatment is planned; Physiologically ‘non-compromised’ – investigation is more limited; it is aimed at establishing whether the patient can be managed nonoperatively, whether angioembolization can be used or whether surgery is required; Physiologically ‘compromised’ – investigations need to be suspended as immediate surgical correction of the bleeding is required. Patient Assessment : The patient’s physiology must be assessed constantly; if there is an indication that the patient is still actively bleeding, the source must be identified unless the patient is unstable and requires immediate surgery. Blood loss into the abdomen can be subtle and there may be no clear clinical signs. Blood is not an irritant and does not initially cause any abdominal pain. Distension is subjective, and a drop in blood pressure may be a very late sign in a young fit patient. Examination of compromised patients should take place either in the emergency department or in the operating theatre if the patient is deteriorating rapidly. Laparotomy : Laparotomy is the final step in the pathway to delineate intra-abdominal injury. Occasionally it is difficult to determine the source of bleeding in shocked, multiple-injured patients. If doubt still exists, especially in the presence of other injuries, a laparotomy may still be the safest option. The key is to make a decision, as indecision leads to a delay in definitive control.

questions.text: Operative management of liver injuries can be sequenced as:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Push, Pringle, Plug, Pack

Highyeild:

The operative management of liver injuries can be summarized as "the Four P's". Push: At laparotomy, the liver is reconstructed and bleeding is controlled by direct bimanual compression. Pringle: Inflow from the portal triad is controlled by a pringle manoeuvre, with direct compression of the portal triad, either digitally or using the soft clamp. Plug: Any holes due to a penetrating injury can be plugged using silicone tubing or sengstaken blakemore tube. Pack: After controlling arterial bleeding, the liver can then be packed.

questions.text: The next line of management in retroperitoneal hematoma involving 'Zone- I' in an unstable patient is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Explore immediately

Highyeild:

Injury to the retroperitoneum is often difficult to diagnose, especially in the presence of other injuries, when the signs may be masked. Diagnostic tests (such as ultrasound and DPL) may be negative. The best diagnostic modality is CT, but this requires a physiologically stable patient . The retroperitoneum is divided into three zones for the purposes of intraoperative management in blunt trauma: Zone 1 (central) : central haematomas should always be explored , once proximal and distal vascular control has been obtained. Zone 2 (lateral) : lateral haematomas should only be explored if they are expanding or pulsatile or if the penetrating injury is present. They are usually renal in origin and can be managed non-operatively, although they may sometimes require angioembolisation. Zone 3 (pelvic) : as with zone 2, these should only be explored if they are expanding or pulsatile or if the penetrating injury is present. Pelvic haematomas are exceptionally difficult to control and, whenever possible, should not be opened; they are best controlled with compression or extraperitoneal packing, or, if the bleeding is arterial in origin, with angioembolisation.
